text: Hey, everyone. Who's doing a great job with B2B case studies. Ideally I'm looking for a variety of exampeles from a variety of industries (not interested in video case studies). Just trying to find some innovative approaches to share with clients and welcome suggestions. No explanaation necessary, but would love any links you can share.

text: Check out the company Forcepoint. Not sure it’s innovative, but it reflects a change in strategy toward deeper storytelling. Contrast that to BigCommerce, which is structured completely differently and mostly represented in the customer’s own words. Those are my last two companies and their approaches struck me as totally different.

text:
I posted a poll on LinkedIn and haven't gotten a ton of traction on it.... I now realize this group might be a more qualified to answer the question I asked. My question is specifically for content marketers in the SaaS industry.

I'm wondering which team handles support questions on your social channels? Our FB is loaded with tech heavy questions that our marketing team isn't equipped to answer. As of now, we just submit those questions as tickets. We're hoping there's a better solution. What does your company do for this? And if you want to jump in on my poll... I'd love some engagement :slightly_smiling_face: <https://www.linkedin.com/feed/update/urn:li:activity:6731639390147289088/>

attachments.title: Alli Tunell on LinkedIn: #SaaS #ContentMarketers #socialmedia
attachments.text: Attention #SaaS #ContentMarketers :mega: How do you handle the support questions that come into your #socialmedia accounts? At BombBomb, our Facebook page...

elements.text:
I posted a poll on LinkedIn and haven't gotten a ton of traction on it.... I now realize this group might be a more qualified to answer the question I asked. My question is specifically for content marketers in the SaaS industry.

I'm wondering which team handles support questions on your social channels? Our FB is loaded with tech heavy questions that our marketing team isn't equipped to answer. As of now, we just submit those questions as tickets. We're hoping there's a better solution. What does your company do for this? And if you want to jump in on my poll... I'd love some engagement

text: I feel quite strongly about this. Support should handle support. You know why? Because they're support!

elements.text: I feel quite strongly about this. Support should handle support. You know why? Because they're support!

text: We use Sprout Social and assign the questions to our support team. They have a rotating support team member for assigned to social.

text:
What are your goals with using it? Eg site auditing or content grading or briefs, etc?

We built a competitive product that overlaps on some brief and grading features and offers some other options as well, so I’m biased, but there are now a bunch of options in the marketplace (that used to just be MarketMuse and Clearscope as recently as early 2019), so many choices depending on what you’re focused on.

text:
Hi <@U013P4Q9YTU>, chiming in from Sprout—right now we don’t support Facebook Groups but I will definitely pass on that suggestion to our product team as we’re actively collecting feedback for this!

On our internal team, our social team has pretty strong product knowledge and can answer many of the support questions (e.g. questions that are really more about product education or explaining the definition of a data point). For more technical questions or something that is an issue, they will task to support. Overnight support covers the Inbox during nights and weekends (leaving marketing messages for the next day), but during the 9-5, marketing team members are the ones reviewing and tasking things out.

elements.text: Hi

, chiming in from Sprout—right now we don’t support Facebook Groups but I will definitely pass on that suggestion to our product team as we’re actively collecting feedback for this!

On our internal team, our social team has pretty strong product knowledge and can answer many of the support questions (e.g. questions that are really more about product education or explaining the definition of a data point). For more technical questions or something that is an issue, they will task to support. Overnight support covers the Inbox during nights and weekends (leaving marketing messages for the next day), but during the 9-5, marketing team members are the ones reviewing and tasking things out.

text: As others have said, let support handle support. Redirect everything to your support app. We don’t get too many questions through Facebook, but I always pass it on to our support team who’ll then handle it.

elements.text: As others have said, let support handle support. Redirect everything to your support app. We don’t get too many questions through Facebook, but I always pass it on to our support team who’ll then handle it.

text: I use Clearscope as well, and am a fan. Best for grading, and has ways you can use it for outlining new content. I've kicked the tires on MarketMuse twice and passed. <@U019E2RJD9Q>’s tool looks pretty solid with some new functionality apparently coming soon too which could potentially put it above Clearscope IMO --but I've yet to test-drive it myself.

elements.text: I use Clearscope as well, and am a fan. Best for grading, and has ways you can use it for outlining new content. I've kicked the tires on MarketMuse twice and passed.
’s tool looks pretty solid with some new functionality apparently coming soon too which could potentially put it above Clearscope IMO --but I've yet to test-drive it myself.

text:
<@UUKNSLX9P> So, the way we set out to solve the problem was to make it easier for strategists to create detailed briefs, and then follow up by grading that content against a topic profile. We're the only ones that approach brief creation the way we do (as something that requires human/strategist input, not a machine-generated export), but there are a lot of different and similar takes on content grading to choose from. MM has some more substantial features like content auditing but historically you've had to pay way more to get those as well. I can't speak to their new pricing that launched recently, not sure what is/isn't included from their product a few years ago.

For our own customers, I know a lot of them prefer to do content audits inside of Ahrefs and URL Profiler to gather quantitative data, and then do qualitative audits and spot checks on individual pieces of content. Likewise, most of our customers have a process in place for keyword-driven content ideation already. So where we fit into the process is once a keyword is selected and you want to do a really deep dive on that single topic.

Would be happy to schedule a demo if you're interested, you can see most of the tool in the video here: <https://www.contentharmony.com/product/>, and we'll have some self sign up options launching soon alongside our content grader.

(Thanks <@U01881ZL1B6> - we think we've got something special but obviously being at feature parity on content grading is a big step for many of our users to consider switching or testing us out.)

attachments.title: Content Brief Software from Content Harmony
attachments.text: We've redesigned the content brief process from the ground up, making it faster, more data-driven, and more *fun* to create briefs for SEO-driven content.
attachments.fallback: Content Harmony: Content Brief Software from Content Harmony

So, the way we set out to solve the problem was to make it easier for strategists to create detailed briefs, and then follow up by grading that content against a topic profile. We're the only ones that approach brief creation the way we do (as something that requires human/strategist input, not a machine-generated export), but there are a lot of different and similar takes on content grading to choose from. MM has some more substantial features like content auditing but historically you've had to pay way more to get those as well. I can't speak to their new pricing that launched recently, not sure what is/isn't included from their product a few years ago.

For our own customers, I know a lot of them prefer to do content audits inside of Ahrefs and URL Profiler to gather quantitative data, and then do qualitative audits and spot checks on individual pieces of content. Likewise, most of our customers have a process in place for keyword-driven content ideation already. So where we fit into the process is once a keyword is selected and you want to do a really deep dive on that single topic.

Would be happy to schedule a demo if you're interested, you can see most of the tool in the video here:
